channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: ã€Swiss Tables are a big plusã€‘ç‘å£«æ¡Œå­å¾ˆå¤§
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹563 â€” July 23, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

How Go 1.24's Swiss Tables 'Saved Us Hundreds of Gigabytes' â€” A look at how the new â€˜Swiss Tablesâ€™ implementation in Go 1.24 helped reduce memory usage in a large in-memory map, how the change was profiled and sized, and a peek at how struct-level optimizations led to even larger fleet-wideÂ savings.

Nayef Ghattas (Datadog)

ğŸ’¡ This post is a strong follow-up to another post: How we tracked down a Go 1.24 memory regression across hundreds ofÂ pods.

Add Enterprise Features, Keep Your Velocity â€” Single sign-on, user provisioning, and role management take time to get right. WorkOS provides clean APIs and reliable infrastructure so your team can stay focused on what makes your product stand out. Trusted by OpenAI, Sourcegraph, andÂ Temporal.

WorkOS sponsor

Go at American Express Today: Seven Key Learnings â€” Itâ€™s always great to read the lessons learned about technology adoption, especially at larger companies. Amex is thriving with Go today (with over 1,000 gophers on staff), but the road wasnâ€™t alwaysÂ smooth.

Benjamin Cane (American Express)

Logging in Go with Slog: A Practitioner's Guide â€” log/slog was introduced in Go 1.21 as the go-to structured log package, and it has many features, many of which are touched on in this comprehensiveÂ tutorial.

Ayooluwa Isiah (Dash0)

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ GopherCon 2025 takes place this August 26-28 in New York City with a great lineup of talks with standard tickets available till nextÂ Tuesday.

  • The tree for Go 1.26 is expected to open today, meaning work on Go 1.26 (fixes first, new features later) can begin in earnest on GitHub.

  • Gofakeit is a Go package for generating random/fake data in hundreds of categories and its author has written about its history and how it's reached 5k stars on GitHub.

  • Google has built a new open-source secrets / credentials scanner in Go called Veles.

Integration Testing for Go Apps using Testcontainers and Containerized Databases â€” Want to test your app against real dependencies without the complexities of managing them (or, worse, running on production services)? Testcontainers provide a way to spin up real services that exist only for the duration of yourÂ tests.

Abhishek Gupta (Microsoft)

ğŸ“„ Tracing Go Apps Using Runtime Tracing and OpenTelemetry Preeti Dewani (Last9)

ğŸ“„ Designing a Composable Rate Limiter clipperhouse

ğŸ“º TinyGo Code Review of a GSM/GPRS Driver Pat Whitti

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

PocketBase: A Go-Powered Backend in One Binary â€” An open source backend app including an embedded SQLite database with realtime subscription support, file and user management, an admin/dashboard UI, and REST API â€“ its main target is for use as a backend to JavaScript frontend apps. Live demo, GitHub repo and niceÂ docs.

Gani Georgiev

Redka: Redis Re-Implemented with SQL â€” A Go-powered data store thatâ€™s compatible with Redisâ€™s API but uses SQL behind the scenes to make it all work. Till now itâ€™s been based on SQLite but v0.6 introduces PostgresÂ support.

Anton Zhiyanov

How to Use Go Tooling + Depotâ€™s API to Outsource Container Builds â€” Stop managing container orchestration complexity. Learn how to use Depot to build untrusted images quickly andÂ securely.

Depot sponsor

go-quartz 0.15: Simple, Zero-Dependency Scheduling Library â€” Inspired by the Quartz scheduler for Java, go-quartz makes it easy to spin up a scheduler within a Go process and trigger functions and jobs on definedÂ schedules.

Eugene R.

  • oauth2-proxy 7.10 â€“ Reverse proxy or middleware for providing OAuthÂ authentication.

  • GitHub MCP Server 0.8 â€“ Yes, GitHub's official MCP server is written inÂ Go.

  • Memos 0.25 â€“ Self-hosted knowledge management and note takingÂ app.

  • BillionMail 4 â€“ Go-powered email campaignÂ platform.

  • rqlite 8.40 â€“ SQLite-backed distributed database.

  • golangci-lint 2.3 â€“ A faster way to run GoÂ linters.

  • quic-go 0.54 â€“ Pure Go QUICÂ implementation.

  • fx 38.0 â€“ The powerful terminal JSONÂ viewer.

ğŸ•¹ï¸ A Blast from the Past..

Gopher2600: An Atari VCS Emulator â€” A mostly feature-complete emulator that includes controller support, gameplay recording, and CRT display effects. Weâ€™ve linked to it a few times over the years, and amazingly itâ€™s still getting significant updates, like in yesterdayâ€™s v0.50.0Â release.

Stephen Illingworth

item.title: ã€Races and memory leaksã€‘ç§æ—å’Œè®°å¿†æ³„æ¼
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹564 â€” July 30, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Hunting a Memory Leak â€” Go has a fantastic runtime and garbage collection but that doesn't mean Go apps are immune to memory leaks. Jason, of the DoltHub team, shares the tale of diagnosing a customer-reported memory leak ultimately caused by improperly closedÂ files.

Jason Fulghum (Dolt)

Go Features by Version (or What's in Which Go) â€” A list of features and the versions in which they first appeared, all the way up to next monthâ€™s expected release of GoÂ 1.25.

Anton Zhiyanov

Kubernetes Cluster Management in 100MB of RAM â€” Portainer is written in Go for speed and efficiency. Manage 200+ Kubernetes clusters from a single control plane using just 100MB of RAM. No bloat, no nonsense; just fast, lightweight cluster management, the GoÂ way.

Portainerâ€¤io sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ GopherCon UK 2025 is taking place in London this August 13-15 for its eleventhÂ run. You can see the jam-packed scheduleÂ here.

  • ğŸ“Š The Stack Overflow 2025 Survey results are out with Go getting some pretty good representation as one of the most admired languages and languages developers aspire toÂ use.

  • As of right now, there's only one 'release blocker' issue for Go 1.25. Final release still expected inÂ August.

Go's Race Detector Has a Mutex Blind Spot â€” A â€˜data raceâ€™ happens when two goroutines concurrently access a shared variable without synchronization and at least one access writes to it. Goâ€™s race detector helps spot these, but itâ€™s not perfect and itâ€™s worth knowing where false negatives canÂ occur.

Double Free Dev

New from Depot: Claude Code Sessions â€” Create, resume, and maintain Claude Code sessions across your entire organization withÂ Depot.

Depot sponsor

ğŸ“„ Parsing Protobuf Like Never Before â€“ Some interesting general Go performance details and a look at Bufâ€™s super fast hyperpb ProtobufÂ parser. Miguel Young de la Sota

ğŸ“„ Interprocedural Analysis: Catch nil Dereferences Before They Crash Your Code â€“ A new feature coming to JetBrains' forthcoming GoLand 2025.2Â release. Arseniy Terekhov (JetBrains)

ğŸ“„ There is No Memory Safety Without Thread Safety Ralf J

ğŸ“„ Implementing Merkle Trees in Go Yoray / Vaktibabat

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

OV: Feature-Rich Terminal Text Viewer/Pager â€” Aims to replace less, tail -f and watch in one. GitHubÂ repo.

Noboru Saito

go-minimp3 1.0: Go Bindings for minimp3 â€” minimp3 is a minimal C library for decoding MP3Â files.

Cowork AI

Pal: A New, Opinionated Dependency Injection Framework â€” â€œPal inherits some design decisions from fx and do and tries to offer the most nondisruptive IoC experience â€¦â€

Gleb Sinyavskiy

hyperpb: 10x Faster Dynamic Protobuf Parsing â€” A fully-dynamic Protobuf parser that boasts being 10x faster than dynamicpb, the standard Go solution for dynamicÂ Protobuf.

Buf

  • Dbmate 2.28 â€“ Framework-agnostic, Go-powered database migrationÂ tool for MySQL, Postgres, SQLite, andÂ ClickHouse.

  • ğŸ¤– MCP-Go 0.36 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP).

  • GoCV 0.42 â€“ Bindings for the OpenCV computer visionÂ library.

  • jwt-go v5.3 â€“ Library to create and verify JSON Web Tokens.

  • Bob v0.39 â€“ SQL query builder and ORM/Factory generator.

  • NATS.go 1.44 â€“ Go client for the NATS messagingÂ system.

  • ğŸ¤– Eino 0.4 â€“ LLM/AI app dev framework for Go.

  • go-github 74.0 â€“ GitHub v3 API clientÂ library.

  • Traefik 3.5 â€“ Popular cloud native appÂ proxy.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Calling all Go devs! We want to learn about the tools you use and features you love. Help us by filling out our survey. You may win aÂ prize.

Join Sticker Mule's "kick ass" team as a Senior Software Engineer! Our teams operate from 17 countries and we're looking for more exceptional engineers.

ğŸ And one for fun..

ZUSE: A Terminal-Based IRC Client â€” For the benefit of anyone younger than me, IRC (Internet Relay Chat) is a very long standing text-based chat system that had its heyday in the 90s and 00s, but is still alive today. This new Go-based IRC client is made with Bubble Tea andÂ Lipgloss.

Baby Commando

P.S. A quick last minute addition before we hit send.. it seems like Charm is cooking up something new.

item.title: ã€An explorer and visualizer for Go concurrency patternsã€‘GOå¹¶å‘æ¨¡å¼çš„æ¢ç´¢å™¨å’Œå¯è§†åŒ–å™¨
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹565 â€” August 6, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

â˜€ï¸ We're taking next week off, so this will be the last issue until Wednesday, August 20. Just a little summer vacation.
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Go Concurrency Explorer and Visualizer â€” After watching Rob Pikeâ€™s â–¶ï¸ talk on Go concurrency patterns, a developer created a live WASM-powered coding environment and visualizer to get a better feel for common concurrency patterns. There are several tutorials to enjoy in here, too.

Richard Chukwu

Build Containers from Scratch â€” Start with raw Linux tools like chroot, namespaces, and cgroups to truly understand how containers work. Then build your own with Docker and deploy them usingÂ Kubernetes.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Crush: Charm's Entry into the AI Coding Agent Space â€” The folks at Charm are well known for their vast array of fantastic Go libraries, like Bubble Tea and Glamour â€“ now theyâ€™ve turned their hand to a Go-powered AI coding agent in a similar vein to ClaudeÂ Code.

Charm

ğŸ’¡ A potentially more interesting part of this is the use of Ultraviolet, a 'set of primitives for manipulating terminal emulators' in dynamic and elaborateÂ ways.

IN BRIEF:

  • GoLand 2025.2, the latest version of JetBrains' popular Go IDE, is out with a variety of minor enhancements.

  • As of Go 1.25, Microsoft's custom builds of Go will default to using system-provided cryptography, previously they used a custom approach to meet Microsoft's internal securityÂ policies.

Go Assembly Mutation Testing â€” Filippo works on Goâ€™s cryptography libraries and for Go 1.26 is exploring a new way to enhance checking the code coverage of tests over this complex, mission critical code. Few readers will need to work this deep, but itâ€™s fascinating to see whatâ€™s going on behind theÂ scenes.

Filippo Valsorda

Be Careful with Go Struct Embedding â€” Embedding structs can quietly mask deeper-nested fields: a duplicate field name isnâ€™t ambiguous unless it appears at the same â€˜depthâ€™, meaning your program may choose an unintendedÂ value.

Matt Hall

ğŸ“„ Building Maybe the Fastest Disk Usage Program on macOS â€“ Building first with Go, then withÂ Rust. Andrew Healey

ğŸ“„ Understanding Reading All Available Things from a Go Channel (with a Timeout) Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ How to Use MongoDB with Go Oluwadamilola Oshungboye

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Statsviz 0.7: Instant Visualization of Your App's Runtime Statistics â€” A way to visualize real time plots of various runtime metrics including heap (size, alloc, etc.), object allocation, goroutines, CPU usage, and more. We first linked to this several years ago, but itâ€™s just had a redesign of itsÂ frontend.

AurÃ©lien Rainone

TreeView: Display Tree Structures at the Terminal â€” A way to display and allow the navigation of tree structures in terminal apps - think things like directory trees, say. It has Bubble Tea and Lip Gloss support and there are numerous visual examples here. GPL 3.0Â licensed.

Digital Shane

Level Up Your Auth for Not Only Your Users, but Also Your AIÂ Agents â€” Auth0 is a full IdP that provides robust security and control over the user experience, from sign-up flows to advancedÂ authorization.

Auth0 sponsor

Inbucket 3.1: A Disposable Webmail Server with SMTP, POP3, and More â€” A self hostable service for testing email â€“ it accepts messages for any email address and makes them available over Web, REST and POP3 interfaces. GitHubÂ repo.

James Hillyerd

dwarfreflect: Enhanced Reflection using DWARF Debug Information â€” Solves the long-standing limitation where Goâ€™s reflect canâ€™t access function parameter names by using DWARF debug information atÂ runtime.
Matteo Grella

cors: A Principled CORS Middleware Library â€” Claims to be â€œperhaps the best CORS middleware library forÂ Go.â€
jub0bs

â˜ï¸Â Stormy: Neofetch-Inspired CLI Weather Displaying Tool
Ashish Kumar

  • go-redis 9.12 â€“ Official Go Redis clientÂ library. Now with Redis 8.2Â support.

  • MCP-Go 0.37 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP).

  • GitHub MCP Server 0.10 â€“ GitHub's official MCP server is written inÂ Go.

  • tbls 1.87 â€“ Auto document a database in MarkdownÂ format.

  • go-elasticsearch 9.1 â€“ Official Elasticsearch clientÂ library.

  • jwt 5.3 â€“ Library to create and verify JSON WebÂ Tokens.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ“œDo you use VS Code for Go development? Weâ€™re keen to learn about the features you love. Fill out our quick survey! You may win aÂ prize!

Join Sticker Mule's "kick ass" team as a Senior Software Engineer! Our team operates from 17 countries and we're looking for more exceptional engineers to joinÂ us.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A roundup of some other interesting stories in the broader developer landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • ğŸ¤– OpenAI has released two significant 'open weight' models that you can run locally for any purpose. The jury is still out on how good they are for coding, but you can easily run them on many modern machines using the Go-powered Ollama.

  • Google has unveiled a new open-licensed code font called Google Sans Code. It has a 'soft' feel to it and is inspired by Google's branding. It's available on Google Fonts too, if you want to quickly plug it into a site.

  • If your knowledge of JavaScript engines and runtimes is limited to V8, Node.js and a few others, this runthrough of the 'many, many, many' JavaScript runtimes of the past decade is for you.

  • â–¶ï¸ An interesting look at what it takes to build a text editor in terms of the algorithms and data structuresÂ required.

  • One developer predicts Rust, Python and TypeScript will become a trifecta of dominant languages goingÂ forward.

  • I just have to admire someone who builds their blog using C preprocessorÂ macros...

ğŸ‘‹ We'll see you again on Wednesday, August 20, but feel free to hit reply and send in any submissions you have for the next issueÂ :-)

ã€‘

auth0

çš„ä¸€æ¬¡æ€§WebMailæœåŠ¡å™¨ - ç”¨äºæµ‹è¯•ç”µå­é‚®ä»¶çš„è‡ªæ‰˜ç®¡æœåŠ¡ - å®ƒæ¥å—ä»»ä½•ç”µå­é‚®ä»¶åœ°å€çš„æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡ç½‘ç»œï¼ŒRESTå’ŒPOP3æ¥å£å¯ç”¨ã€‚ github repoã€‚

- è§£å†³äº†é•¿æœŸå­˜åœ¨çš„é™åˆ¶ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­GOçš„åå°„æ— æ³•é€šè¿‡åœ¨è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä½¿ç”¨çŸ®äººè°ƒè¯•ä¿¡æ¯è®¿é—®å‡½æ•°å‚æ•°åç§°ã€‚
matteo grella

- å£°ç§°ä¸ºâ€œä¹Ÿè®¸GOçš„æœ€ä½³CORSä¸­é—´ä»¶åº“ã€‚â€
jub0bs

â˜ï¸
ashish kumar

item.title: ã€The one with the big Go 1.25 releaseã€‘å¤§GO 1.25å‘è¡Œ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹566 â€” August 20, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

â˜€ï¸ We're back from a week off â€“ the previous issue is here if you want to check it out again â€“ and we should now be back every week until October at leastÂ :-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

â­Â Go 1.25 Released â€” Sadly Go 1.25â€™s release coincided with my vacation â€“ what luck! Nonetheless, 1.25 is a solid release, focused on fixes, improvements, and tool upgrades, rather than language changes, making it an easy upgrade for most. Here are some of the highlights and further resources to checkÂ out:

  • The final Go 1.25 release notes provide all the details of the release.
  • A new, experimental garbage collector is available to try, behind the GOEXPERIMENT=greenteagc build-time option.
  • Anton Zhiyanov's Go 1.25 interactive tour remains a great way to get up to speed with the few language tweaks there are, including WaitGroup.Go(), the v2 JSON package, and the now-generally-available testing/synctestÂ package.
  • Microsoft has issued a release of its own Go 1.25.0 build and *TinyGo* has a Go 1.25 build too (more on that below).

Dmitri Shuralyov (The Go Team)

Take Control of User Roles and Permissions â€” As your app grows, hard-coded roles and permissions become messy and slow development. WorkOS RBAC makes it easy to define roles, group permissions, and manage access at scale with simple APIs, a powerful dashboard, and native SSO and SCIMÂ integrations.

WorkOS sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Amazon Web Services has created an 'Advanced Go Driver' for Amazon RDS and Aurora that wraps pgx or the native MySQL driver to provide enhanced functionality, particularly around auth and switchover/failoverÂ scenarios.

  • Embedded Go is a Go toolchain that adapts the Go compiler to target alternative devices including the Raspberry Pi Pico 2 and even the NintendoÂ 64.

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ Jamie Tanna shares a detailed writeup of his experiences at last week's GopherCon UKÂ 2025.

D2: A Declarative Diagramming Tool in Go â€” If youâ€™re familiar with Mermaid, this is a similar idea but built in Go. Itâ€™s a powerful tool, and has become even more so this week with support for ASCII outputs, so you can use your diagrams in even more places. GitHubÂ repo.

Terrastruct

What is the Go Proxy Even Doing? â€” Goâ€™s module proxy provides stability for developers, but its design can hit upstream servers with redundant clones. Ted shows the logs and explains how he defends hisÂ server.

Ted Unangst

ğŸ“„ From Python to Go: Why We Rewrote Our Ingest Pipeline â€“ They started with Python for faster prototyping but rapidly saw huge gains after shifting toÂ Go. Telemetry Harbor

ğŸ“„ Understanding Go Error Types: Pointer vs. Value â€“ â€œThe subtle distinction between pointer and value error types can silently break yourÂ code.â€ Fillmore Labs

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Introducing gomjml: MJML Email Markup for Go Developers â€” MJML is a framework for writing emails using special, custom HTML tags which then get transformed into safe, responsive HTML that notoriously touchy email clients can handle. MJMLâ€™s main implementation is for Node.js, however, but Preslav has built a new, Go-nativeÂ approach.

Preslav Rachev

TinyGo 0.39: Now with Go 1.25 Support â€” TinyGo is a popular Go compiler that takes Go to â€˜small placesâ€™ like embedded systems, microcontrollers and WebAssembly use cases. v0.39 is a bigger release than it sounds as it brings Go 1.25Â support.

  • Ginkgo 2.24 â€“ Mature testingÂ framework. A new semantic versioning filter has been added so you can run specs based on versionÂ constraints.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A roundup of other interesting stories from the broader developer landscape:

  • GitHub's CEO, Thomas Dohmke, has stood down and with it, GitHub has been rolled into Microsoft's 'CoreAI' organization more completely.

  • If you've never quite got your head around SVGs (Scalable Vector Graphics) and how paths are defined in them, Josh W Comeau has a new, fantastic guide to SVG paths.

  • Redis 8.2, the latest version of the popular data structure store/database, has been released. Over 70 commands now run faster than in Redis 8.0 and I/O threads now enable significant concurrent performance gains. Some neat memory usage reductions featureÂ too.]

  • GitHub's Taylor Blau shares some highlights from this week's GitÂ 2.51Â release.
